facts.text: On April 6, 1951, the appellant company entered into a contract with the respondent company for the supply of 5,000 maunds of Nikhli and/or Ashuganj Jute on certain prices according to quality, shipment during July and/or August, 1951.
The contract contained a very wide arbitration clause and was entered into by bought and sold notes exchanged between the parties through brokers.

Shipping documents were presented to the respondent company by the bankers of the appellant company but were not honoured on the plea that the same were not in order; respondent failed to take delivery of the goods. Last presentation date: September 17, 1951.

On September 26, 1951, appellant company through solicitors wrote to respondent company intimating cancellation of contract and demanding Rs. 1,95,000 as damages based on difference between contract price and market price on September 17, 1951.
Respondent company by letter dated October 25, 1951, denied liability to pay any amount.
On November 2, 1951, appellant company referred the dispute to arbitration of Bengal Chamber of Commerce in terms of arbitration clause.
Respondent company submitted to jurisdiction of arbitration tribunal by appearing and adducing evidence.
On February 29, 1952, arbitrators made award allowing appellant's claim in full with interest and costs (Award No. 209 of 1952 in case No. 855 of 1951).
Award filed in Calcutta High Court on April 23, 1952.

On June 9, 1952, respondent company filed application in Calcutta High Court to declare award null and void, main ground: contract void under Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1951 (Ben. VI of 1951).

Contract entered through normal trade channels, not in manner specified in Act or rules; no application under s.6(1), no selection of buyer under s.6(2), no written intention by respondent, no specified date, delivery period in contravention.
Learned Single Judge referred matter to Chief Justice for larger Bench; Special Bench constituted.
High Court by judgment dated January 23, 1953, allowed respondent's application, declared award null and void, parties to bear own costs.
West Bengal Jute (Control of Prices) Act, 1950 (W. Ben. VI of 1950) came into force March 15, 1950.
Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Ordinance, 1950 (XVII of 1950) promulgated December 14, 1950.
Notification dated December 29, 1950, specified December 30, 1950, as appointed day for ss.5,6,7 of Ordinance.

Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1951 (W. Ben. VI of 1951) came into force March 21, 1951; ss.1-15 verbatim from Ordinance; s.16 deems Ordinance actions under Act as from Dec 14, 1950.
Act repealed August 5, 1952.
Central Jute Board issued circulars authorizing jute mills to purchase quotas through normal trade channels subject to furnishing particulars.
Appeal filed upon certificate of fitness granted by Calcutta High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 5, 6 and 7 of the Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1951, were brought into force by the notification dated December 29, 1950.
Whether the Act was ultra vires the Bengal Legislature.
Whether there was a subsequent independent agreement to refer disputes to arbitration of Bengal Chamber of Commerce.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if the Act were intra vires, ss. 5, 6 and 7 were never brought into force; notification dated December 29, 1950, specified appointed day for ss.5,6,7 of the Ordinance, not the Act; s.16 deems it issued under Act but fiction ends there; notification makes no sense under Act without altering terms.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.16 of Raw Jute Act 1951; Hamilton and Co. v. Mackie and Sons; T.W. Thomas Co. v. Portsea Steamship Co.

respondent_arguments.text: Contract void under s.5(2) of the Act as not entered in manner provided in s.6; ss.5,6,7 in force via notification deemed under Act.

court_reasoning.text: Notification under Ordinance deemed issued under Act by s.16; twin fictions (Act commenced Dec 14, 1950; notification under Act) require reading mutatis mutandis, substituting 'Act' for 'Ordinance' in notification to give full effect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fiction extends to reading notification as issued under Act, compelling substitution of words.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents distinguished: no statutory deeming provision there like s.16 here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.16 creates fictions requiring full effect via mutatis mutandis principle.

holdings.text: Notification dated December 29, 1950, read mutatis mutandis under s.16, brings ss.5,6,7 of Act into force from December 30, 1950; contract void, award null and void.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hamilton and Co. v. Mackie and Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: No statutory deeming of charter party clause into bill of lading; here s.16 requires full fictional effect.

precedents_cited.case_name: T.W. Thomas Co. Limited v. Portsea Steamship Company Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Hamilton; arbitration clause from charter party senseless in bill of lading without deeming provision like s.16.

statutes_cited.name: Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1951 (W. Ben. Act VI of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Contract void under s.5(2) if not per s.6; ss.5,6,7 brought into force via deemed notification; s.16 deems Ordinance actions under Act.

statutes_cited.name: Raw Jute Central Jute Board and Miscellaneous Provisions Ordinance, 1950 (XVII of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced by Act; notification specified appointed day for ss.5,6,7; deemed under Act by s.16.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Jute (Control of Prices) Act, 1950 (W. Ben. VI of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Preceded Ordinance; fixed maximum prices leading to need for Central Jute Board.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court's judgment declaring award null and void upheld as contract void under ss.5,6,7 of Raw Jute Act 1951, brought into force by notification read mutatis mutandis under s.16.

key_quotes.text: "We cannot read it as having been issued under the Act unless we read the word 'Ordinance' used in the notification as 'Act'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on effect of s.16 fictions requiring mutatis mutandis reading.

key_quotes.text: "The creation of the statutory fictions compels us to adopt the principle of mutatis mutandis and to substitute the word 'Act' for the word 'Ordinance' used in the notification."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains how notification applies to Act's sections.
